Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The flight-fecundity tradeoff - functional physiology and fitness
Award.AbstractNarration: Organisms have finite amounts of energy to use for growth, maintenance, survival and reproduction. Allocation of energy to any one of these functions reduces the amount available for any of the other functions. Such tradeoffs in energy allocation lie at the foundation of any organism's ecological and evolutionary success as it directly affects an organism's ability to produce offspring. Tradeoffs are fluid, constantly changing with the ecological conditions encountered. Knowledge of the physiological priorities that govern these allocation decisions within an individual is essential for achieving a deeper understanding of constraints or limits on tradeoffs. An individual-level understanding of energy allocation strategies is remarkably rare. This study will examine the functional physiology that prioritizes the energy allocation tradeoff between flight and fecundity, two traits with high-energy demand, in the hawkmoth Manduca sexta (Sphingidae). An innovative approach that combines state of the art respirometry and laser carbon stable isotope analyzer systems will, for the first time, address the functional physiology of this significant tradeoff at the level of the individual in a way that has not previously been possible. This project will combine experiments in nutrient acquisition and allocation, metabolism and stable isotopes into one integrative study in ecological physiology, all in a realistic ecological context. The conceptual breadth of this study will generate integrative research training for a postdoc, and graduate and undergraduate students. In addition, this project will support and enhance Insect Discovery, an existing outreach program that reaches over 2000 elementary school children annually with hands-on, inquiry-based, STEM outreach that meets Arizona State Science Standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organisms such as insects allocate the nutrients they acquire from feeding to support various functions such as growth, maintenance, survival and reproduction. In this study we examined how caterpillars and moths allocate their resources (nutrients) to support these different functions.

Some major findings:

i)     Using a vertical wind tunnel, we found that larger females allocate more resources to flight and are able to carry larger payloads (nectar and eggs) than smaller females. Males, in contrast, invest fewer resources to flight and are able to carry only smaller payloads. Interestingly, this pattern flips on a low quality diet: larger males invest more in flight than smaller males, and males in general invest more than do females. This suggests that when resources are limited, males invest more resources into flight to ensure their ability to find a mate.

ii)   Diet quality also affects resource allocation strategies to different brain functions. Larger females allocate fewer resources to the parts of the brain that are involved in memory, learning and decision making compared to smaller females, whereas males maintain a constant allocation to these brain functions. This suggests that females emerge from the pupa with ‘sufficient’ data processing ability to find host plants and can allocate resources to other functions, whereas males need a constant high level of data processing to find females. Our overall conclusion from this work is that the nutritional history of the caterpillar, whether it fed on a high or low quality diet, reprograms resource allocation during metamorphosis that results in functionally different adults

We pioneered a unique combined respirometry and carbon stable isotope system that allows us to track the allocation and metabolic fate of fatty acids, amino acids and carbohydrates literally second by second, and throughout the lifetime of an individual. We used this system to understand how resources that pollinators such as moths get from nectar are utilized.

Pollinators are often attracted to flowers for the nectar rewards. Nectar, however, is more than just sugar and water; it can also contain amino acids, fatty acids and microbes. We tracked the fate of these nectar components using the respirometry and stable carbon isotopes system just described.

Some major findings:

i)              Nectar-feeding animals that migrate long distances such as monarch butterflies, hummingbirds, and bats have high aerobic performance which also causes oxidative damage in muscles. Nectar lacks antioxidants. We showed that nectarivores generate antioxidant potential to mitigate the oxidative damage caused by the muscular demands of flight by shunting nectar glucose to the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), which generates NADPH and glutathione, two major antioxidants.

ii)            Moths were fed nectars spiked with labeled (13C) amino acids and fatty acids and showed that nonessential amino acids are allocated to reproduction then quickly broken down in the offspring whereas the essential amino acids are allocated to reproduction but maintained in the offspring. All amino acids were used as metabolic fuel, but the non-essential amino acids are oxidized at higher rates. Surprisingly, the nectar fatty acids were not transferred to offspring, but were used as a metabolic fuel by the moth, minimizing losses of endogenous nutrient stores.

iii)          Females mated to fed males laid more eggs than those mated to unfed males. Using 13C-enriched glucose in the nectar of the fed males, we found that the 2nd and 3rd spermataphore (structure used to transfer sperm and other proteins) of males were strongly labeled, but this labeled glucose was not present either in the female's body or in her eggs. Therefore, although fed males provided females with direct benefits from the sugar in the nectar, females did not use the sugar as a nutrient.

iv)            A well-established paradigm of resource utilization during starvation in vertebrates is that they first deplete carbohydrates, then lipids, and only then, use proteins as a fuel source for basic metabolism (protein sparing). Using 13C labeled amino acids and fatty acids in a diversity of insect species and life stages, we show that this paradigm does not hold for insects: starving insects employ a wide range of strategies for regulating lipid and protein oxidation. 

This grant supported Insect Discovery an outreach program that teaches biological principals to 2nd and 3rd graders using insects. Over the duration of this grant, Insect Discovery has served 612 classrooms in 206 schools, conducted 220 workshops and 558 classroom visits, reaching a total of 14,994 school children. In addition, 206 undergraduate preceptors and 20 graduate students have been trained in science outreach. In addition, this grant also supported the Arizona Insect Festival, a yearly outreach event to educate the public about insects and has over 6,000 visitors each year.
